As e-commerce continues to expand globally, it faces increasing risks from both criminal and deviant behaviors. The framework aims to delineate the actions and behaviors of cybercriminals and non-criminal deviants, offering a comprehensive approach to cybersecurity and fraud prevention. By examining the distinctions between criminal and unethical activities, it provides e-commerce organizations with actionable insights to enhance their cyber incident response strategies. The proposed framework not only aids in understanding cyber offender behavior but also contributes to the broader field of cybercrime profiling. This research is critical for e-commerce stakeholders, including merchants and financial institutions, who must navigate the complexities of cyber threats in their daily operations.

articles.title: Faith, Not Trance: A Rational Refutation of Zindler's Thesis on Religion and Hypnosis
articles.authors: Osama S Qatrani
articles.abstract:
This paper offers a critical response to Frank Zindler‚Äôs 1984 essay ‚ÄúReligion, Hypnosis, and 
Music: An Evolutionary Perspective.‚Äù Zindler proposes that religious experience is a 
neurobiological byproduct of hypnotic suggestibility and musical stimulation‚Äîan adaptive 
illusion rather than a valid epistemic framework. While acknowledging Zindler‚Äôs historical 
context and intellectual sincerity, this paper challenges the reductionist nature of his claims. It 
argues that religion cannot be adequately explained through neurochemical responses or group 
selection theory alone. Drawing on interdisciplinary evidence from neurotheology, 
anthropology, and philosophy of mind, the paper presents religion as a structured moral and 
metaphysical system, not a cognitive glitch. It highlights the philosophical inconsistencies in 
equating evolutionary utility with truth, and critiques the ideological bias in scientific 
reductionism. The paper also emphasizes the civilizational role of religion in shaping ethics, 
science, art, and human dignity across cultures. Ultimately, it calls for a deeper, fairer dialogue 
between religious traditions and secular critiques‚Äîone that respects the complexity of spiritual 
experience and the quest for meaning. Religion is not merely survival-driven illusion; it is a 
human expression of transcendence, justice, and moral awakening. Zindler‚Äôs thesis raises 
valuable questions‚Äîbut fails to capture the full cognitive, ethical, and historical dimensions of 
religious consciousness.

articles.title: Capital Conversion and the Hysteresis Effect in Urban Poverty: Relational Barriers to Labour Market Participation
articles.authors: Floris Noordhoff
articles.abstract: This article examines how individuals in persistent urban poverty attempt to access the labour market through capital conversion strategies, and how these efforts are shaped by the hysteresis effect. Drawing on Bourdieu‚Äôs field theory and relational sociology, the study analyses how people try to re-enter employment by converting social, cultural, and symbolic capital into labour market opportunities. Based on qualitative fieldwork in disadvantaged neighbourhoods in Rotterdam and Amsterdam, the research highlights how mismatches between habitus and the structural logic of the labour market produce friction, failure, and exclusion. The hysteresis effect‚Äîwhere past experiences and expectations lag behind current field demands‚Äîhelps explain why job-seeking efforts often misfire, despite high motivation or informal skill sets. Respondents struggle with institutionalised expectations of employability, bureaucratic eligibility criteria, and the erosion of informal networks that once facilitated access to work. These findings show that labour market exclusion is not only a matter of lacking resources, but also of symbolic disqualification and misrecognition. The article contributes to scholarship on poverty, labour markets, and agency by demonstrating how structural inequality is reproduced through field-specific logics, and how relational forms of agency both resist and reinforce these mechanisms.

articles.title: Centros de Datos, Minerales Cr√≠ticos, Energ√≠a y Geopol√≠tica: las bases de la Inteligencia Artificial
articles.authors: Jo√£o Henrique Santana Stacciarini; Ricardo Junior de Assis Fernandes Gon√ßalves
articles.abstract: La inteligencia artificial (IA) se ha expandido significativamente en los √∫ltimos a√±os, impregnando diversos sectores de la econom√≠a y de la vida cotidiana. Sin embargo, esta r√°pida adopci√≥n exige un an√°lisis de las contrapartidas asociadas a su funcionamiento, muchas veces desconocidas por el p√∫blico. Con base en un an√°lisis de datos extra√≠dos de art√≠culos acad√©micos, informes t√©cnicos, repositorios de datos y documentos gubernamentales, este art√≠culo explora las dimensiones f√≠sicas, energ√©ticas y geopol√≠ticas subyacentes a la IA. Aunque a menudo se percibe como inmaterial, la IA depende de una vasta y compleja infraestructura f√≠sica, sostenida por centros de datos que albergan miles de equipos fabricados a partir de una amplia gama de minerales y metales, muchos de ellos clasificados como cr√≠ticos. Actualmente, existen alrededor de 12 mil centros de datos en operaci√≥n a nivel mundial, incluidos 992 de hiperescala, que ocupan √°reas de miles de metros cuadrados. El corto ciclo de vida de los equipos de estos centros, combinado con una eliminaci√≥n inadecuada, excluye metales valiosos de la cadena de suministro, intensificando la extracci√≥n mineral y agravando los impactos socioambientales. Paralelamente, la disputa entre Estados Unidos y China por el control de minerales cr√≠ticos y por el liderazgo en tecnolog√≠as de IA ha intensificado las tensiones geopol√≠ticas, con restricciones mutuas a la exportaci√≥n de tecnolog√≠as avanzadas y minerales esenciales. Otro aspecto relevante es el alto consumo energ√©tico de las aplicaciones de IA: en Estados Unidos, los centros de datos ya representan cerca del 4% del consumo nacional de electricidad, con una previsi√≥n de alcanzar el 9,1% para 2030. Aunque las grandes empresas tecnol√≥gicas invierten en fuentes renovables, como la solar y la e√≥lica, para satisfacer esta creciente demanda, dichas fuentes tambi√©n requieren vol√∫menes significativos de minerales cr√≠ticos. Este conjunto de factores evidencia la compleja interconexi√≥n entre Inteligencia Artificial, Centros de Datos, Minerales Cr√≠ticos, Energ√≠a y Geopol√≠tica.

articles.title: Policy brief: Pol√≠tica p√∫blica para prevenir la obesidad en j√≥venes y adultos enfocado en el contexto universitario colombiano, integrando experiencias de M√©xico y Per√∫
articles.authors: Maria Ca√±on Aranguren; Andrea S√°nchez Osorio; Valeria Escutia Montemayor; Anais Corina Huapaya Cordova; Sandra Nicol Villanueva Quispe; Francisco Palencia-S√°nchez
articles.abstract: La obesidad es un problema de alto impacto que influye de manera significativa en la salud de las personas y en el sistema que las rodea y que responde a una etiolog√≠a multidimensional fundamentada en los determinantes sociales de la salud. Por ello es fundamental su estudio, y su caracterizaci√≥n a trav√©s de encuestas de situaci√≥n nutricional. Adicionalmente, se recomendar√°n estrategias de pol√≠ticas p√∫blicas en Colombia encaminadas hacia el mejoramiento de la salud de las comunidades a trav√©s del fomento de la alimentaci√≥n balanceada y actividad f√≠sica en la poblaci√≥n universitaria teniendo en cuenta perspectivas de M√©xico y Per√∫.

articles.title: Probability and the philosophies of science: A realist view
articles.authors: Connor Donegan
articles.abstract: Like causality, probability is a critical concept in the conflict between contending philosophies of science. Unlike causality, a canonically `realist' view of probability appears elusive. This paper examines and strengthens the connections between realism and the epistemological theory of probability (EP), sometimes known as probability as logic or plausible reasoning. Following the likes of Keynes, Jeffreys, P√≥lya, and Jaynes, the EP tradition provides a framework for the study of non-demonstrative logic which hinges on an implicit concept of logical structure. EP advanced historically via critiques of positivism in physics and of the scepticism of Hume and Popper. EP also shares with realist philosophy a critique of a characteristic feature of empiricist philosophy‚Äîits explicit conflation of ontology and epistemology. To illustrate the normative value of this framework, I apply P√≥lya's theory of analogy to a portion of Galileo's classic argument that the earth is in motion.

articles.title: Collaborative problem framing at scale on an online platform for professionals
articles.authors: Alena Seredko
articles.abstract: This study investigates how collaborative problem framing is accomplished at scale on Stack Overflow, a large-scale online community question answering platform for software developers. Drawing on the practice-based theoretical perspective, the study examines how users coordinate problem framing through interactions with one another and with the platform via asking, commenting on, and editing questions. Based on the sequential analysis of four Stack Overflow threads, the findings specify the role of dynamic jointly created profession specific objects in producing broadly intelligible and solvable problems. The study also unpacks how the technical features of the platform, more specifically the dynamics of the dual space of editing and commenting, enable problem framing and solving to unfold at scale. Finally, the findings unpack interactional strategies enacted by users to coordinate problem framing on the large-scale platform. The study suggests contributions to the fields of professional learning and design of online environments aimed to support problem solving and collaborative activities more broadly.

articles.title: Studying Agency Under Constraint: A Relational Field Methodology (Part 1)
articles.authors: Floris Noordhoff
articles.abstract: This article presents a relational methodology for studying poverty, agency, and morality under structural constraint. It addresses the limitations of both individualistic and deterministic approaches by conceptualising agency as a situated capacity, shaped by capital, power relations, and moral boundaries across multiple social fields. Drawing on Bourdieu‚Äôs field theory, the methodology traces how disadvantaged individuals navigate complex environments such as welfare systems, labour markets, and informal economies. The proposed design integrates ethnographic observation, in-depth interviews, and abductive analysis. Core concepts include habitus, capital conversion, symbolic violence, and moral boundary-work. These help reveal how practical logics‚Äîroutine, situated judgments‚Äîguide action under duress. A key contribution is the operationalisation of relational agency, using Emirbayer and Mische‚Äôs temporal framework to capture how people draw on past experiences and future aspirations. This method is especially suited for researchers exploring how poor individuals actively respond to constraint without reducing them to passive victims. It also supports methodological pluralism by combining theory-driven coding with inductive fieldwork. Overall, the article provides a robust and flexible toolkit for analysing agency and inequality through relational sociology.
